description:
Goose calicivirus is a member of the Caliciviridae family, a group of non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses. It is specifically associated with geese and has been identified as a causative agent of viral enteritis, a gastrointestinal disease, in these birds.

The virus particle is approximately 27-35 nanometers in diameter and has a characteristic icosahedral capsid structure, a hallmark of caliciviruses. The viral genome is approximately 7.5-8.3 kilobases in length and encodes for essential proteins involved in viral replication and host cell interaction.

Goose calicivirus is primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route, with infected geese shedding the virus in their feces. The virus can then be ingested by other geese, leading to the spread of the infection within a flock. The virus primarily targets the intestinal epithelial cells, causing inflammation, diarrhea, and other gastrointestinal symptoms in affected birds.

Outbreaks of goose calicivirus infections have been reported in various regions, particularly in areas with intensive goose farming practices. Effective biosecurity measures, proper hygiene, and vaccination strategies are important in controlling and preventing the spread of this viral disease among goose populations.
